html.p: Dubh.Org is a web server which is mostly dedicated to the development and support of several open source projects and other assorted technologies I feel like experimenting with on any given day.

The server is maintained by Brian Duff. My surname, as well as being the drink particularly favoured by Homer Simpson & chums is actually derived from the Gaelic dubh, meaning black. It seemed like as good a name as any for a web site and no-one else was using it, so here we are...
This site is an "evolved" version of my homepage, which has been around since the glorious early web days of mid 1994.

Dubh.Org runs on a Cobalt RAQ3 dedicated server with a T1 connection running Cobalt's slightly modified version of Red Hat Linux. I'm renting the server from UK2NET, whom I heartily recommend if, like me, you want to mess about with up to date technologies like servlets and xml, but your ISP doesn't allow this kind of thing on their web servers.

I divide development of this site at home between my main PC (a 1GHz PIII Dell Dimension 4100 with 256Mb) and my slightly punier 650MHz PIII Dell Inspiron 7500 laptop. OK, So I'm showing off. These numbers won't be so impressive in about a years time when I next edit this page :). Again, Dell did a great job with both computers.

I use the Oracle XSQL Servlet, Oracle XSLT Transformer and Oracle XML Parser to dynamically transform XML documents on the server. This technology lets me just define the content for each page in XML, and dynamically build up all the other stuff (heading, footer, navigator etc.), the layout and the style.

The XSQL servlet is also used to pull data out of the MySQL database I have on my server in XML format and transform it to readable HTML. (I'd use Oracle, but trying to upload it to my server would be immensely time consuming, and MySQL came preinstalled on the RAQ. Then there are the licensing issues...).

The XSQL Servlet relies on servlets and JDBC, two integral components of Java 2 Enterprise Edition. The Tomcat Servlet Engine is a key technology - a cleanly implemented, open source servlet engine, which is now the reference servlet implementation for Java 2 EE. The Apache Web Server is used to serve static content.

For the online CVS browser, I'm using the JCVS Servlet. I'm a great believer in SCM, so everything (including all the pages and configurations for this web site) is in a CVS repository on this server.

Any servlets I develop myself, and any other Java code I write for the site is currently developed using Oracle JDeveloper 9i (I work on the development team at Oracle for this product). In a few weeks time, I'll probably switch over to the first internal alpha of JDeveloper 9i, the new all-Java IDE that's under development at Oracle.
I'm hosting a few other sites on this server. I'm happy to do this for people I can trust who need more space for web pages or want to play with neato technologies on their pages.
Better Bites is the sandwich shop owned by my parents. I wrote a wee web page for them.
Leaping Frogs is a site owned by a mate of mine from University.
